key_points: Vice President Kamala Harris addressed the Commission on the Status of Women, highlighting the importance of the commission since 1947.
Harris emphasized the intrinsic link between democracy and gender equality, stating democracy should ensure every citizen has an equal voice.
She reported a troubling 15-year decline in global freedom, marking the past year as the worst for global democracy and freedom.
In light of current global health and economic crises, Harris stressed the importance of defending democracy.
The United States is strengthening engagement with the United Nations and rejoining the Human Rights Council.
The status of democracy is fundamentally linked to the empowerment of women, with their participation strengthening democracy.
Harris noted progress in the United States, including the historic participation of women in elections, Congress, and leadership roles.
COVID-19 has posed significant threats to women's economic, physical security, and health worldwide.
The United States has re-engaged with the World Health Organization and is revitalizing partnerships to empower women globally.
Harris concluded by committing to uphold democratic values and improve the status of women, echoing Eleanor Roosevelt's view on democracy and equality.
